questions.text: A 42-year-old man comes to the physician because he is concerned that he is balding. Over the past few months, he has noticed patchy areas of hair loss on his head. He also mentions that he has felt depressed since the death of his wife last year and has unintentionally lost about 18 kg (40 lb). He is constantly fatigued. He has little appetite because he feels food does not taste the same way anymore. He also has occasional episodes of watery diarrhea. He drinks 5–6 cans of beer daily. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows dry, scaly skin on both feet. There is patchy alopecia of the scalp, axillae, chest, and mons pubis. Which of the following is most likely to improve this patient's alopecia?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Finasteride is used to treat androgenetic alopecia. While the condition is the most common cause of alopecia in men and should always be considered, the hair typically recedes in an M-shaped pattern along the hairline. Patchy, generalized hair loss and gastrointestinal symptoms cannot be explained by androgenetic alopecia.
Image Description:

Non-scarring hair loss can be seen at the temporal scalp.

This is the characteristic pattern of male pattern hair loss.

B) INCORRECT:

Griseofulvin is a medication used to treat fungal infections, including conditions like tinea capitis. While tinea capitis impairs hair growth and can cause alopecia, it almost exclusively affects the scalp and manifests with pruritic, round scaly plaques that are not present in this patient.
Image Description:

Scalp of a child

There is a round, almost hairless plaque with coarse scaling.

The patient was diagnosed with superficial tinea capitis caused by dermatophytes.

C) CORRECT:

This patient presents with symptoms of zinc deficiency (diarrhea, dermatitis, abnormal taste, alopecia), which is most likely caused by insufficient dietary intake and chronic heavy alcohol use. Oral zinc supplementation is the most effective treatment for managing symptoms of deficiency as well as restoring normal hair growth.

D) INCORRECT:

Levothyroxine administration is indicated in individuals with hypothyroidism. Although hypothyroidism can also cause hair loss and fatigue, it typically leads to weight gain and constipation and is therefore unlikely to be the cause of this patient's symptoms.

E) INCORRECT:

Triamcinolone is a corticosteroid that is used to treat alopecia areata, a condition that causes patchy hair loss and that can affect any part of the body. Since the disease typically manifests with an acute onset in individuals < 30 years of age and is not associated with skin lesions or gastrointestinal complaints, this diagnosis is unlikely.
Image Description:

There are well-demarcated, patchy areas of hair loss without scarring of the scalp.

F) INCORRECT:

Habit reversal training is used for the treatment of trichotillomania, a disorder characterized by the compulsion to pull out one's hair, which leads to nonscarring, patchy hair loss. Although trichotillomania is associated with other psychiatric conditions that may be present in this patient (e.g., major depressive disorder) and could have been triggered by his wife's death, he shows no uncontrollable urge to pull his hair.
Image Description:

There are patches of hair of varying length. The hair density is normal (including new hair growth).
questions.hint: Patients with this diagnosis may also have delayed wound healing and hypogonadism.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of hair loss and a rash on her face. She has also noticed that food has recently tasted bland to her. Her medical history is remarkable for Crohn disease, for which she had to undergo segmental small bowel resection several times because of intestinal obstruction and fistula formation. She was previously started on infliximab, which she stopped taking 9 months ago. Examination shows several bullous, erythematous perioral plaques. There are two well-circumscribed circular patches of hair loss on her scalp. A deficiency of which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Retinoic acid (vitamin A) deficiency can manifest with dry, scaly skin (xerosis cutis). However, this patient lacks other typical features of vitamin A deficiency, such as night blindness, xerophthalmia, and corneal degeneration. Moreover, perioral plaques, altered sense of taste, and alopecia are not consistent with this deficiency.

B) INCORRECT:

Ascorbic acid (vitamin C) deficiency (also known as scurvy) can manifest with dermatitis. However, this patient lacks typical features of vitamin C deficiency, such as gingivitis, mucosal bleeding, curly body hair, arthralgia, and follicular hyperkeratosis. Finally, altered sense of taste and alopecia are not commonly seen in scurvy.

C) INCORRECT:

Niacin deficiency (also known as pellagra) can manifest with dermatitis. However, dermatitis associated with pellagra typically manifests as a symmetrical rash with hyperpigmented lesions on sun-exposed areas. This patient lacks additional features of niacin deficiency, such as glossitis, dementia, and diarrhea. Finally, altered sense of taste and alopecia are not consistent with pellagra.
Image Description:

Pellagra can be deadly if left untreated (due to the formerly high mortality rate, “death” is sometimes still listed as the fourth “D” of pellagra). Populations with a diet low in niacin-rich foods (e.g., corn-based diets without proper preparation) are at higher risk.

D) INCORRECT:

Cobalamin (Vitamin B12) deficiency can be seen in patients with inflammation of the terminal ileum (e.g., as seen in Crohn disease), where cobalamin is absorbed. This deficiency typically manifests with dry skin and altered taste sensation. However, other features of cobalamin deficiency, such as fatigue, peripheral neuropathy, symmetric paresthesias, numbness, and gait abnormalities, are absent in this patient. Moreover, cobalamin deficiency does not explain this patient's erythematous perioral plaques.

E) INCORRECT:

Selenium deficiency is a very rare nutritional deficiency that occurs most often in populations dependent on selenium-depleted soil for agriculture. Known manifestations of selenium deficiency include hypothyroidism (as thyroid hormone production is dependent on selenium) and myocardial necrosis leading to heart failure (for reasons that remain unclear). This patient's symptoms are not consistent with selenium deficiency.

F) INCORRECT:

Iron deficiency may also cause hair loss, which is seen in this patient. Furthermore, because iron is normally absorbed in the duodenum, Crohn disease is a risk factor for this type of deficiency. Iron deficiency most commonly manifests with easy fatigability, shortness of breath, conjunctival pallor, and weakness (all attributable to iron deficiency anemia), as well as koilonychia and pica. This patient lacks these other cardinal findings. Moreover, iron deficiency would not explain this patient's dysgeusia and dermatitis.

G) CORRECT:

Zinc deficiency can lead to a constellation of clinical features including immune dysfunction, impaired wound healing, hypogonadism, diarrhea, dermatitis, alopecia, abnormal sense of taste (dysgeusia), and an abnormal sense of smell (dysosmia). Etiologies include poor dietary intake, impaired absorption (e.g., due to Crohn disease), congenital conditions (e.g., acrodermatitis enteropathica), and liver or renal disease. Crohn disease and numerous small bowel resections have most likely substantially impaired this patient's ability to absorb zinc, thereby predisposing her to zinc deficiency.

Zinc is a mineral that is vital for the function of numerous enzymes and is essential for the synthesis of zinc-finger transcription factors.
questions.hint: A congenital cause of the same deficiency is Acrodermatitis enteropathica, which can manifest with depressed immunity, resulting in frequent infections and, in males, decreased spermatogenesis.

questions.text:
A 47-year-old woman with small intestinal Crohn disease who is receiving mesalamine and oral budesonide has had persistent diarrhea, worsening oral lesions, and recurrent blisters on her extremities during the past month. She has four to six loose bowel movements daily. She also notes fatigue and changes in her sense of taste.
On physical examination, she has whitish 1- to 2-cm plaques on her buccal mucosa, along with an erythematous, scaly, and vesicular rash near her groin and on her hands, knees, and feet (figure). She does not have epidermal sloughing with tangential pressure on the skin. She has no abdominal tenderness, and her neurologic examination is unremarkable.
The results of a complete blood count, comprehensive metabolic panel, liver function tests, thyrotropin level, vitamin B12 level, and C-reactive protein level are normal.
Which one of the following treatments is most likely to alleviate this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Fluconazole is not indicated, as the constellation of features is not typical of a systemic fungal infection.

B) CORRECT:

Zinc is predominantly absorbed in the small bowel; as a result, zinc deficiency can occur in 40% to 50% of adults with Crohn disease. Zinc deficiency can cause fatigue, alopecia, abnormalities in taste sensation, poor wound healing, night blindness, hypogonadism, diarrhea, and an acquired acrodermatitis enteropathica-like syndrome, which manifests as erythematous, vesiculobullous skin changes. The treatment for this syndrome is zinc supplementation.

Key learning point: Patients with small intestinal disease are at risk for acrodermatitis enteropathica caused by a deficiency in zinc.

C) INCORRECT:

Deficiency in vitamin A, a fat-soluble vitamin, can produce a follicular hyperkeratotic rash and abnormalities in patients’ sense of taste and smell. Vitamin A deficiency is most typically associated with liver or biliary disease.

D) INCORRECT:

Niacin deficiency typically causes a dermatitis characterized by a hyperpigmented rash in sun-exposed areas, as well as glossitis, angular stomatitis, diarrhea, and dementia. It commonly occurs in association with malabsorptive syndromes, carcinoid syndrome, isoniazid therapy, and chronic alcoholism.

E) INCORRECT:

Budesonide can result in glucocorticoid-related side effects, such as bruising and acne, but it would not cause the type of rash seen in this patient.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old man presents with fatigue. He reports that for the past two years, he has taken several tablets of zinc daily to prevent colds.
His laboratory results are as follows:



Patient value
Reference range


Leukocyte count (per mm3)
1400
4500–11,000


Hemoglobin (g/dL)
7.5
13.5–17.5


Platelet count (per mm3)
90,000
150,000–350,000



Mean corpuscular volume (μm3)
105
80–100


Deficiency of which one of the following dietary components is this patient most likely to have?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Manganese deficiency is not typically associated with anemia.

B) INCORRECT:

Vitamin C deficiency causes scurvy, which is characterized by malaise, lethargy, myalgias, bruising, petechiae, gum disease, loosening of the teeth, and poor wound healing, but not anemia.

C) CORRECT:

Pancytopenia with macrocytic anemia suggests myelodysplastic syndrome, especially in older patients. Before a diagnosis of myelodysplastic syndrome is made, however, it is important to rule out reversible causes of bone-marrow dysfunction, including deficiencies in copper, vitamin B12, and folic acid.

Etiologies of copper deficiency include excessive zinc intake, malabsorptive diseases, prior bowel resection, and bariatric surgery or gastrectomy.

Key learning point: The mineral deficiency that can manifest with features of myelodysplastic syndrome is copper deficiency.

D) INCORRECT:

Vitamin A deficiency causes night blindness but is not associated with anemia.

E) INCORRECT:

Iron deficiency would cause microcytosis, not macrocytosis, and would not cause pancytopenia.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a 2-week history of hair loss and a facial rash. She also reports that food has recently tasted bland. Her medical history includes Crohn disease, and she has undergone multiple segmental small bowel resections due to intestinal obstruction and fistula formation. She was previously started on infliximab, which she discontinued 9 months ago. On examination, you observe several bullous, erythematous perioral plaques and two well-circumscribed circular patches of hair loss on her scalp. A deficiency of which one of the following is the most likely cause of her condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Retinoic acid (vitamin A) deficiency can manifest with dry, scaly skin (xerosis cutis). However, this patient lacks other typical features of vitamin A deficiency, such as night blindness, xerophthalmia, and corneal degeneration. Moreover, perioral plaques, altered sense of taste, and alopecia are not consistent with this deficiency.

B) INCORRECT:

Cobalamin (Vitamin B12) deficiency can be seen in patients with inflammation of the terminal ileum (e.g., as seen in Crohn disease), where cobalamin is absorbed. This deficiency typically manifests with dry skin and altered taste sensation. However, other features of cobalamin deficiency, such as fatigue, peripheral neuropathy, symmetric paresthesias, numbness, and gait abnormalities, are absent in this patient. Moreover, cobalamin deficiency does not explain this patient's erythematous perioral plaques.

C) INCORRECT:

Ascorbic acid (vitamin C) deficiency (also known as scurvy) can manifest with dermatitis. However, this patient lacks typical features of vitamin C deficiency, such as gingivitis, mucosal bleeding, curly body hair, arthralgia, and follicular hyperkeratosis. Finally, altered sense of taste and alopecia are not commonly seen in scurvy.

D) CORRECT:

Zinc deficiency can lead to a constellation of clinical features including immune dysfunction, impaired wound healing, hypogonadism, diarrhea, dermatitis, alopecia, abnormal sense of taste (dysgeusia), and an abnormal sense of smell (dysosmia). Etiologies include poor dietary intake, impaired absorption (e.g., due to Crohn disease), congenital conditions (e.g., acrodermatitis enteropathica), and liver or renal disease. Crohn disease and numerous small bowel resections have most likely substantially impaired this patient's ability to absorb zinc, thereby predisposing her to zinc deficiency.

Zinc is a mineral that is vital for the function of numerous enzymes and is essential for the synthesis of zinc-finger transcription factors.

Key learning point: Zinc deficiency commonly causes perioral dermatitis, alopecia, and dysgeusia, especially in individuals with impaired intestinal absorption such as those with Crohn disease or extensive small bowel resection.

E) INCORRECT:

Niacin deficiency (also known as pellagra) can manifest with dermatitis. However, dermatitis associated with pellagra typically manifests as a symmetrical rash with hyperpigmented lesions on sun-exposed areas. This patient lacks additional features of niacin deficiency, such as glossitis, dementia, and diarrhea. Finally, altered sense of taste and alopecia are not consistent with pellagra.
questions.hint: A congenital cause of the same deficiency is Acrodermatitis enteropathica, which can manifest with depressed immunity, resulting in frequent infections and, in males, decreased spermatogenesis.
